newsitem.title: ITALY: Advertisement has Pisa officials in towering rage.
newsitem.headline: Advertisement has Pisa officials in towering rage.

text.p: The mayor of Pisa is not inclined to see the funny side of an advertisement which shows his city's leaning tower toppling over.
The ad' at the centre of the controversy was for an Italian insurance firm seeking a new angle.
A recent double-page image in Italian newspapers showed a red station wagon reversing into and toppling the leaning tower. The catchline: "You hadn't planned for this. We had".
Pisa mayor Piero Floriani said."If people want to use the tower for publicity they should make sure they do it in good taste. Alluding to the collapse of the tower is in bad taste,"
He said the tower, which has leaned ever since its completion around 1350, was still in danger of collapsing after restructuring work was halted in October last year.
Ranieri Favilli, who is in charge of the restructuring work said the advertisment was "counterproductive" at a time when they were trying to restart work to save the tower.
The insurance company, RAS, had no comment.
